title: Gaspar da Cruz
text:
Gaspar da Cruz ( 1520 – 5 February 1570; sometimes also known under an Hispanized version of his name, Gaspar de la Cruz) was a <a href="Portuguese%20people">Portuguese</a> <a href="Dominican%20Order">Dominican</a> friar born in <a href="%C3%89vora">Évora</a>, who traveled to Asia and wrote one of the first detailed European accounts about <a href="China">China</a>.
Biography.
Gaspar da Cruz was admitted to <a href="Dominican%20Order">the Order of Preachers (Dominican order)</a> convent of <a href="Azeit%C3%A3o">Azeitão</a>. In 1548, along with 10 other <a href="friar">friar</a>s. Gaspar da Cruz embarked for <a href="Portuguese%20India">Portuguese India</a> under the orders of Friar Diogo Bermudes, with the purpose of founding a Dominican <a href="Mission%20%28Christian%29">mission</a> in the East. For six years, Cruz remained in <a href="Hindustan">Hindustan</a>, probably in <a href="Goa">Goa</a>, <a href="Chaul">Chaul</a> and <a href="Kochi%2C%20India">Kochi</a>, as his Order had established a settlement there. During this time he also visited <a href="Portuguese%20Ceylon">Portuguese Ceylon</a>.
In 1554, Cruz was in <a href="Portuguese%20Malacca">Malacca</a>, where he founded a house under his Order, living there until September 1555. He was then shipped to <a href="Cambodia">Cambodia</a>. Given the failure of the Cambodian mission, in late 1556 Cruz went to <a href="Lampacao">Lampacao</a>, a small island in the <a href="Guangzhou">Guangzhou</a> bay, six leagues north of <a href="Shangchuan%20Island">Shangchuan Island</a> (Sanchão). At that time, Lamapacao island was a port for trade with the Chinese. At Lampacao, he was able to obtain a permission to go to Guangzhou, and spent a month preaching there.
In 1557, Cruz returned to Malacca.
In 1560, Cruz headed to <a href="Hormuz%20Island">Hormuz</a> where he gave support to soldiers of the Portuguese fort. He probably returned to India about 3 years later, although there are no definite records for this period. It is likely that Cruz returned to Portugal in 1565, returning to Lisbon in 1569, where he was documented helping victims of the <a href="Bubonic%20plague">plague</a>. He later returned to his convent in <a href="Set%C3%BAbal">Setúbal</a> where he died of the plague on February 5, 1570.
"A Treatise of China".
Cruz's book, "Tratado das cousas da China" (Treatise on things Chinese) was published by André de Burgos, of <a href="%C3%89vora">Évora</a>, in 1569. The full title, in the original orthography, was "Tractado em que se cõtam muito por estẽso as cousas da China". It is often described as the first European book whose main topic was China; at any rate, it is one of the first undisputed books on China published in Europe since that of <a href="Marco%20Polo">Marco Polo</a>.
The book also contains accounts of Cambodia and Hormuz.
Influence.
In <a href="Donald%20F.%20Lach">Donald F. Lach</a>'s assessment, Cruz' book itself did not become widely distributed in Europe either because it was published in Portuguese (rather than some more widely spoken language), or because it appeared in the year of the <a href="plague%20%28disease%29">plague</a>. Nonetheless, Cruz' book, at least indirectly, played a key role in forming the European view of China in the sixteenth century, alongside the earlier and shorter account by <a href="Galeote%20Pereira">Galeote Pereira</a> (1565). Cruz' "Treatise" (along with <a href="Jo%C3%A3o%20de%20Barros">João de Barros</a>' earlier coverage of China in his "Decadas") was the main source of information for <a href="Bernardino%20de%20Escalante">Bernardino de Escalante</a>'s "Discourso ... de las grandezas del Reino de la China" (1577), and one of the main sources for the much more famous and widely translated "<a href="The%20history%20of%20the%20great%20and%20mighty%20kingdom%20of%20China%20and%20the%20situation%20thereof">History of the great and mighty kingdom of China</a>" compiled by <a href="Juan%20Gonz%C3%A1lez%20de%20Mendoza">Juan González de Mendoza</a> in 1585.
While Escalante's and Mendoza's works were translated into many European languages within a few years after the appearance of the Spanish original (the English versions were published in 1579 and 1588, respectively), Cruz' text only appeared in English in 1625, in <a href="Samuel%20Purchas">Samuel Purchas</a>' "Purchas his Pilgrimes", and even then only in an abridged form, as "A Treatise of China and the adjoining regions, written by Gaspar da Cruz a Dominican Friar, and dedicated to Sebastian, King of Portugal: here abbreviated". By this time his report had been superseded not only by Mendoza's celebrated treatise, but also by the much more informed work of <a href="Matteo%20Ricci">Matteo Ricci</a> and <a href="Nicolas%20Trigault">Nicolas Trigault</a>, "<a href="De%20Christiana%20expeditione%20apud%20Sinas">De Christiana expeditione apud Sinas</a>" (Latin 1616; English abridgment, in the same Purchas' collection of 1625).
Chinese language and writing.
Reading Gaspar da Cruz' "Treatise", one has an impression that, as of 1555, communication between the Portuguese and the Chinese was accomplished primarily thanks to the existence of some Chinese people able to speak Portuguese, rather than the other way around. His book several times mentions Chinese interpreters working with Portuguese, but never a Portuguese person speaking or reading Chinese. (This was not any different from the situation that obtained in the accounts of da Cruz' Spanish colleague <a href="Mart%C3%ADn%20de%20Rada">Martín de Rada</a>'s expedition to <a href="Fujian">Fujian</a> in 1575). The Portuguese, of course, "did" know some Chinese words and common expressions: da Cruz' book contains, for example, titles of various officials, or the word "cha" ("<a href="History%20of%20tea">tea</a>").
Da Cruz was, however, curious about the Chinese writing system, and gave a brief report of it, which <a href="John%20DeFrancis">John DeFrancis</a> has described as "the first Western account of the fascinatingly different Chinese writing."
Slavery.
One of the major irritants in the early <a href="Sino-Portuguese%20relations">Sino-Portuguese relations</a> was the Portuguese' proclivity to <a href="Slavery%20in%20Portugal">enslave</a> Chinese children and take them to various Portuguese colonies, or to Portugal itself. While this traffic was on a much smaller scale than the <a href="Atlantic%20slave%20trade">Atlantic slave trade</a>, supplying millions of African <a href="Slavery%20in%20Brazil">slaves for Portuguese Brazil</a>, it was a contributing factor already to the failure of the <a href="Tom%C3%A9%20Pires">Tomé Pires</a>' 1521 embassy, when, in a words of a later researcher, many residents of Canton discovered that "many of their children, whom they had given in pledge to their creditors, had been kidnapped by" <a href="Sim%C3%A3o%20de%20Andrade">Simão de Andrade</a> "and carried away to become slaves".
Gaspar da Cruz was aware of this trade, and, as his book (Chapter XV) implies, he had heard of the Portuguese slavers' attempts to justify their actions by claiming that they had been merely buying children that already were slaves while in China. Da Cruz described the situation with <a href="slavery%20in%20China">slavery in China</a> as he saw it. According to him, the laws of China allowed impoverished widows to sell her children; however, the conditions under which boys or girls sold into servitude could be kept were regulated by law and custom, and upon reaching a certain age they had to be set free. Reselling of such slaves (or, rather, bond-servants) was regulated too, there being "great penalties" for selling any of them to the Portuguese. He concludes therefore (as <a href="C.R.%20Boxer">C.R. Boxer</a> summarizes his argument), that "the Portuguese had no legal or moral rights to purchase either "<a href="Mui%20Tsai">mui-tsai</a>" or kidnapped children for use as slaves":
God's punishment for sins.
In the first paragraph of the last chapter (XXIX) of his book Cruz severely criticized "a filthy abomination, which is that they are so given to the accursed sin of <a href="sodomy">unnatural vice</a>, which is in no way reproved among them." The rest of the chapter, entitled "Of some punishments from God which the Chinas received in the year of fifty-six", discusses the <a href="1556%20Shaanxi%20earthquake">1556 Shaanxi earthquake</a> and certain flooding events of the same year, which da Cruz views as God's punishment for "this sin".
